case_name: Income-tax Officer v. Messrs. K. Y. Pilliah Sons

facts.text: Respondents Messrs. K. Y. Pilliah Sons declared Rs. 18,679 as their income from business in return for assessment year 1951-52

anchor.surface_text: In their return of income for the assessment year 1951-52 the respondents, Messrs. K. Y. Pilliah Sons, declared Rs. 18,679 as their income from business.

facts.text: Assessee carried on business of purchasing and selling cloth

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer discovered that in the business of purchasing and selling cloth carried on by the assessee

facts.text: ITO rejected assessee claim of net turnover Rs. 9,42,524-8-9 and estimated turnover at Rs. 12 lakhs with gross profit at 6.5%

On the facts disclosed, the Income-tax Officer could exercise, the power to estimate the turnover. The power must of course be exercised not arbitrarily, but judicially in the light of relevant materials. It is, however, not even suggested that the Income-tax Officer acted arbitrarily or capriciously in exercising his power to estimate the undisclosed turnover. The estimate made by the Income-tax Officer was affirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal is the final fact-finding authority and normally it should record its conclusion on every disputed question raised before, it setting out its reasons in support of its conclusion. But, in failing to record reasons, when the Appellate Tribunal fully agrees with the view expressed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and has no other ground to record in support of its conclusion, it does not act illegally or irregularly, merely because it does not repeat the grounds of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner

arguments.claim: Gross profit rate of 6.5% on estimated turnover reasonable as normal rate for similar business is 6 to 7%

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer companyputed the profits from the business at a flat rate. The gross profits disclosed by the assessees yielded a rate of 3.8. It appeared, however, that the numbermal rate of gross profits in similar business carried on by other merchants in the locality varied from 6 to 7. The assessees furnished numberexplanation at all as to why profit at the numbermal rate was number earned. Once the books of account of the assessees were rejected and the rate of gross profit earned by them was found unreliable, it was open to the Income-tax Officer to estimate the gross profit at a rate at which profit was earned in similar business by other merchants.

holdings.text: The Income-tax Officer could exercise the power to estimate the turnover when books are unreliable. The power must be exercised not arbitrarily, but judicially in the light of relevant materials.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts disclosed, the Income-tax Officer could exercise, the power to estimate the turnover. The power must of course be exercised not arbitrarily, but judicially in the light of relevant materials. It is, however, not even suggested that the Income-tax Officer acted arbitrarily or capriciously in exercising his power to estimate the undisclosed turnover. The estimate made by the Income-tax Officer was affirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Tribunal.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Books unreliable due to admitted suppressed sales over Rs.1 lakh, low gross profit rate compared to peers, non-production of vouchers; estimate affirmed by AAC and Tribunal without allegation of arbitrariness.

holdings.text: Reasons recorded by the Tribunal supporting levy on profits computed on estimated turnover of Rs.12 lakhs at 6.5% rate were not irrelevant; habit of suppressing sales and purchases, admission of unreported sales for tax saving are relevant considerations.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court at the hearing of the reference was of the view that the Appellate Tribunal was strongly influenced by the fact that the assessees were in the habit of suppressing not only the sales but the corresponding purchases as well and also by the admission made before the Income-tax Officer that certain sales had not passed through the books of account with a view to saving sales tax. These, in the view of the High Court, were irrelevant considerations

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects High Court's view; these factors justify rejection of books and judicial estimation of true turnover and profits.

holdings.text: Once books rejected and disclosed gross profit rate unreliable, Income-tax Officer can estimate gross profit at normal rate earned in similar business by other merchants (6-7%).

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer computed the profits from the business at a flat rate. The gross profits disclosed by the assessees yielded a rate of 3.8. It appeared, however, that the normal rate of gross profits in similar business carried on by other merchants in the locality varied from 6 to 7.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessee's 3.8% rate abnormally low vs. peers' 6-7%; no explanation provided; aligns with affirmed estimate.

holdings.text: Tribunal justified in sustaining addition of Rs.41,142 as business income from estimated profits.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer worked out the gross profit on the estimated turnover of Rs. 12 lakhs at 6.5 and that the profit amounted to Rs. 78,000. The assessees had by their return disclosed a gross profit of Rs. 36,858.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Difference between estimated gross profit Rs.78,000 and disclosed Rs.36,858; no other outgoings claimed; falls under first question.

holdings.text: Assessee's explanation for Rs.7,000 cash credits untrue as Sampangappa admitted inability to advance funds; correctly treated as income from undisclosed sources.

anchor.surface_text: The assessees had credited Sampangappa with two sums of Rs. 6,000 and Rs. 1,000 in the months of November and December, 1950, respectively. It was clear that Sampangappa had not advanced at the material time any amount to the assessees. The explanation of the assessees was, therefore, untrue.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Creditor's admission disproves loan; no evidence of actual payment beyond book entries.

holdings.text: No evidence furnished linking Rs.7,000 cash credits to secreted profits already brought to tax; Tribunal justified in taxing separately.

anchor.surface_text: It was urged before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Tribunal that the amount of Rs. 7,000 could still be attributed to the secreted profits. But no such explanation was furnished by the assessees and if the Tribunal declined to accept that contention, no question of law arises from its finding in that behalf.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessee failed to provide explanation connecting credit to estimated business profits.

holdings.text: Tribunal, as final fact-finding authority, need not independently record reasons if it fully agrees with Appellate Assistant Commissioner and has no additional grounds.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal is the final fact-finding authority and normally it should record its conclusion on every disputed question raised before it setting out its reasons in support of its conclusion. But, in failing to record reasons, when the Appellate Tribunal fully agrees with the view expressed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and has no other ground to record in support of its conclusion, it does not act illegally or irregularly, merely because it does not repeat the grounds of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects High Court's criticism of Tribunal for merely affirming AAC without independent reasons; no illegality in agreement without repetition.

holdings.text: Sustaining additions of Rs.41,142 business income and Rs.7,000 cash credits does not result in double taxation.

anchor.surface_text: It cannot be said that the Tribunal was not justified in bringing to tax the amount of Rs. 7,000, and no question of double taxation arises.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Additions under distinct heads; no proof cash credits part of estimated profits already taxed.

holdings.text: First question answered in the negative; second question in the affirmative on the first part, second part does not fall to be determined.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative holdings on relevant considerations for estimate, justification for both additions, no double taxation issue arising.

anchor.surface_text: The appeal will therefore be allowed and the two questions referred to the High Court will be answered as follows In the negative. In the affirmative on the first part of the question the second part does

outcome.relief_summary: Appeal of the Commissioner of Income-tax allowed; High Court judgment reversed by answering the referred questions in favour of the revenue: first question in the negative, second question in the affirmative on the first part (sustaining additions justified) with second part not arising.
directions: First question answered in the negative.
Second question answered in the affirmative on the first part; the second part does not fall to be determined.

anchor.surface_text: On the facts disclosed, the Income-tax Officer could exercise, the power to estimate the turnover. The power must of course be exercised not arbitrarily, but judicially in the light of relevant materials. It is, however, not even suggested that the Income-tax Officer acted arbitrarily or capriciously in exercising his power to estimate the undisclosed turnover. The estimate made by the Income-tax Officer was affirmed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Tribunal.

The appeal will therefore be allowed and the two questions referred to the High Court will be answered as follows In the negative. In the affirmative on the first part of the question the second part does

anchor.surface_text: The High Court at the hearing of the reference was of the view that the Appellate Tribunal was strongly influenced by the fact that the assessees were in the habit of suppressing not only the sales but the corresponding purchases as well and also by the admission made before the Income-tax Officer that certain sales had not passed through the books of account with a view to saving sales tax. These, in the view of the High Court, were irrelevant considerations

The appeal will therefore be allowed and the two questions referred to the High Court will be answered as follows In the negative. In the affirmative on the first part of the question the second part does

edges.explanation: h3 addresses i1 by justifying estimation method after book rejection

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer computed the profits from the business at a flat rate. The gross profits disclosed by the assessees yielded a rate of 3.8. It appeared, however, that the normal rate of gross profits in similar business carried on by other merchants in the locality varied from 6 to 7.

The appeal will therefore be allowed and the two questions referred to the High Court will be answered as follows In the negative. In the affirmative on the first part of the question the second part does

anchor.surface_text: The assessees had credited Sampangappa with two sums of Rs. 6,000 and Rs. 1,000 in the months of November and December, 1950, respectively. It was clear that Sampangappa had not advanced at the material time any amount to the assessees. The explanation of the assessees was, therefore, untrue.

The appeal will therefore be allowed and the two questions referred to the High Court will be answered as follows In the negative. In the affirmative on the first part of the question the second part does

anchor.surface_text: It was urged before the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and the Tribunal that the amount of Rs. 7,000 could still be attributed to the secreted profits. But no such explanation was furnished by the assessees and if the Tribunal declined to accept that contention, no question of law arises from its finding in that behalf.

The appeal will therefore be allowed and the two questions referred to the High Court will be answered as follows In the negative. In the affirmative on the first part of the question the second part does

edges.explanation: h7 holds Tribunal need not record independent reasons if agreeing, justifying its sustaining of additions

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Appellate Tribunal is the final fact-finding authority and normally it should record its conclusion on every disputed question raised before it setting out its reasons in support of its conclusion. But, in failing to record reasons, when the Appellate Tribunal fully agrees with the view expressed by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner and has no other ground to record in support of its conclusion, it does not act illegally or irregularly, merely because it does not repeat the grounds of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner

The appeal will therefore be allowed and the two questions referred to the High Court will be answered as follows In the negative. In the affirmative on the first part of the question the second part does
